trans-unit.source: Managing concurrency in a cache
trans-unit.target: Managing concurrency in a cache

trans-unit.source: Caches are often designed to be shared by multiple instances of an
trans-unit.target: Caches are often designed to be shared by multiple instances of an

trans-unit.source: application.
trans-unit.target: application.

trans-unit.source: Each application instance can read and modify data in
trans-unit.target: Each application instance can read and modify data in

trans-unit.source: the cache.
trans-unit.target: the cache.

trans-unit.source: Consequently, the same concurrency issues that arise with
trans-unit.target: Consequently, the same concurrency issues that arise with

trans-unit.source: any shared data store are also applicable to a cache.
trans-unit.target: any shared data store are also applicable to a cache.

trans-unit.source: In a situation
trans-unit.target: In a situation

trans-unit.source: where an application needs to modify data held in the cache, you may
trans-unit.target: where an application needs to modify data held in the cache, you may

trans-unit.source: need to ensure that updates made by one instance of the application
trans-unit.target: need to ensure that updates made by one instance of the application

trans-unit.source: do not blindly overwrite the changes made by another instance.
trans-unit.target: do not blindly overwrite the changes made by another instance.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the nature of the data and the likelihood of collisions,
trans-unit.target: Depending on the nature of the data and the likelihood of collisions,

trans-unit.source: you can adopt one of two approaches to concurrency:
trans-unit.target: you can adopt one of two approaches to concurrency:

trans-unit.source: Optimistic.
trans-unit.target: Optimistic.

trans-unit.source: The application checks to see whether the data in the cache has changed since it was retrieved, immediately prior to updating it.
trans-unit.target: The application checks to see whether the data in the cache has changed since it was retrieved, immediately prior to updating it.

trans-unit.source: If the data is still the same, the change can be made.
trans-unit.target: If the data is still the same, the change can be made.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the application has to decide whether to update it (the business logic that drives this decision will be application-specific).
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the application has to decide whether to update it (the business logic that drives this decision will be application-specific).

trans-unit.source: This approach is suitable for situations where updates are infrequent, or where collisions are unlikely to occur.
trans-unit.target: This approach is suitable for situations where updates are infrequent, or where collisions are unlikely to occur.

trans-unit.source: Pessimistic.
trans-unit.target: Pessimistic.

trans-unit.source: The application locks the data in the cache when it retrieves it to prevent another instance from changing the data.
trans-unit.target: The application locks the data in the cache when it retrieves it to prevent another instance from changing the data.

trans-unit.source: This process ensures that collisions cannot occur, but could block other instances that need to process the same data.
trans-unit.target: This process ensures that collisions cannot occur, but could block other instances that need to process the same data.

trans-unit.source: Pessimistic concurrency can affect the scalability of the solution and should be used only for short-lived operations.
trans-unit.target: Pessimistic concurrency can affect the scalability of the solution and should be used only for short-lived operations.

trans-unit.source: This approach may be appropriate for situations where collisions are more likely, especially if an application updates multiple items in the cache and must ensure that these changes are applied consistently.
trans-unit.target: This approach may be appropriate for situations where collisions are more likely, especially if an application updates multiple items in the cache and must ensure that these changes are applied consistently.

trans-unit.source: Features of Redis
trans-unit.target: Features of Redis

trans-unit.source: Redis is more than a simple cache server; it provides a distributed in-memory
trans-unit.target: Redis is more than a simple cache server; it provides a distributed in-memory

trans-unit.source: database with an extensive command set that supports many common scenarios,
trans-unit.target: database with an extensive command set that supports many common scenarios,

trans-unit.source: as described in the section Use-cases for Redis caching later in this
trans-unit.target: as described in the section Use-cases for Redis caching later in this

trans-unit.target: document.

trans-unit.source: This section summarizes some of the key features that Redis
trans-unit.target: This section summarizes some of the key features that Redis

trans-unit.source: provides.
trans-unit.target: provides.

trans-unit.source: Redis as an in-memory database
trans-unit.target: Redis as an in-memory database

trans-unit.source: Redis supports both reading and writing operations.
trans-unit.target: Redis supports both reading and writing operations.

trans-unit.source: Unlike many caches (which should be considered as transitory data stores), writes can be protected from system failure either by being stored in periodically in a local snapshot file or in an append-only log file.
trans-unit.target: Unlike many caches (which should be considered as transitory data stores), writes can be protected from system failure either by being stored in periodically in a local snapshot file or in an append-only log file.

trans-unit.source: All writes are asynchronous and do not block clients reading and writing data.
trans-unit.target: All writes are asynchronous and do not block clients reading and writing data.

trans-unit.source: When Redis starts running, it reads the data from the snapshot or log file and uses it to construct the in-memory cache.
trans-unit.target: When Redis starts running, it reads the data from the snapshot or log file and uses it to construct the in-memory cache.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Redis Persistence](http://redis.io/topics/persistence) on the Redis website.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Redis Persistence](http://redis.io/topics/persistence) on the Redis website.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Redis does not guarantee that all writes will be saved in the event
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Redis does not guarantee that all writes will be saved in the event

trans-unit.source: of a catastrophic failure, but at worst you should only lose a few-seconds
trans-unit.target: of a catastrophic failure, but at worst you should only lose a few-seconds

trans-unit.source: worth of data.
trans-unit.target: worth of data.

trans-unit.source: Remember that a cache is not intended to act as an
trans-unit.target: Remember that a cache is not intended to act as an

trans-unit.target: authoritative data source, and it is the responsibility of the applications

trans-unit.target: using the cache to ensure that critical data is saved successfully to an

trans-unit.target: appropriate data store.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the Cache-Aside pattern.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the Cache-Aside pattern.

trans-unit.source: Redis data types
trans-unit.target: Redis data types

trans-unit.source: Redis is a key-value store, where values can contain simple types or complex data structures such as hashes, lists, and sets.
trans-unit.target: Redis is a key-value store, where values can contain simple types or complex data structures such as hashes, lists, and sets.

trans-unit.source: It supports a set of atomic operations on these data types.
trans-unit.target: It supports a set of atomic operations on these data types.

trans-unit.source: Keys can be permanent or tagged with a limited time to live at which point the key and its corresponding value are automatically removed from the cache.
trans-unit.target: Keys can be permanent or tagged with a limited time to live at which point the key and its corresponding value are automatically removed from the cache.

trans-unit.source: For more information about redis keys and values, visit the page [An Introduction to Redis data types and abstractions](http://redis.io/topics/data-types-intro) on the Redis website.
trans-unit.target: For more information about redis keys and values, visit the page [An Introduction to Redis data types and abstractions](http://redis.io/topics/data-types-intro) on the Redis website.

trans-unit.source: Redis replication and clustering
trans-unit.target: Redis replication and clustering

trans-unit.source: Redis supports master/subordinate replication to help ensure availability and maintain throughput; write operations to a Redis master node are replicated to one or more subordinate nodes, and read operations can be served by the master or any of the subordinates.
trans-unit.target: Redis supports master/subordinate replication to help ensure availability and maintain throughput; write operations to a Redis master node are replicated to one or more subordinate nodes, and read operations can be served by the master or any of the subordinates.

trans-unit.source: In the event of a network partition, subordinates can continue to serve data and then transparently resynchronize with the master when the connection is reestablished.
trans-unit.target: In the event of a network partition, subordinates can continue to serve data and then transparently resynchronize with the master when the connection is reestablished.

trans-unit.source: For further details, visit the [Replication](http://redis.io/topics/replication) page on the Redis website.
trans-unit.target: For further details, visit the [Replication](http://redis.io/topics/replication) page on the Redis website.

trans-unit.source: Redis also provides clustering, enabling you to transparently partition data into shards across servers and spread the load.
trans-unit.target: Redis also provides clustering, enabling you to transparently partition data into shards across servers and spread the load.

trans-unit.source: This feature improves scalability as new Redis servers can be added and the data repartitioned as the size of the cache increases.
trans-unit.target: This feature improves scalability as new Redis servers can be added and the data repartitioned as the size of the cache increases.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, each server in the cluster can be replicated by using master/subordinate replication to ensure availability across each node in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, each server in the cluster can be replicated by using master/subordinate replication to ensure availability across each node in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: For more information about clustering and sharding, visit the [Redis Cluster Tutorial page](http://redis.io/topics/cluster-tutorial) on the Redis website.
trans-unit.target: For more information about clustering and sharding, visit the [Redis Cluster Tutorial page](http://redis.io/topics/cluster-tutorial) on the Redis website.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Redis Cache does not currently support clustering.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Redis Cache does not currently support clustering.

trans-unit.source: If you wish to create a Redis cluster you can build your own custom Redis server.
trans-unit.target: If you wish to create a Redis cluster you can build your own custom Redis server.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the section Building a Custom Redis Cache later in this document.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the section Building a Custom Redis Cache later in this document.

trans-unit.source: Redis memory use
trans-unit.target: Redis memory use

trans-unit.source: A Redis cache has a finite size depending on the resources available on the host computer.
trans-unit.target: A Redis cache has a finite size depending on the resources available on the host computer.

trans-unit.source: When you configure a Redis server, you can specify the maximum amount of memory it can use.
trans-unit.target: When you configure a Redis server, you can specify the maximum amount of memory it can use.

trans-unit.source: A key in a Redis cache can be configured with an expiration time, after which it is automatically removed from the cache.
trans-unit.target: A key in a Redis cache can be configured with an expiration time, after which it is automatically removed from the cache.

trans-unit.source: This feature can help prevent the in-memory cache from being filled with old or stale data.
trans-unit.target: This feature can help prevent the in-memory cache from being filled with old or stale data.

trans-unit.source: As memory fills up, Redis can automatically evict keys and their values by following a number of policies.
trans-unit.target: As memory fills up, Redis can automatically evict keys and their values by following a number of policies.

trans-unit.source: The default is LRU (least recently used), but you can also select other policies such as evicting keys at random, or turning off eviction altogether (in which case, attempts to add items to the cache will fail if it is full).
trans-unit.target: The default is LRU (least recently used), but you can also select other policies such as evicting keys at random, or turning off eviction altogether (in which case, attempts to add items to the cache will fail if it is full).

trans-unit.source: The page [Using Redis as an LRU Cache](http://redis.io/topics/lru-cache) provides more information.
trans-unit.target: The page [Using Redis as an LRU Cache](http://redis.io/topics/lru-cache) provides more information.

trans-unit.source: Redis transactions and batches
trans-unit.target: Redis transactions and batches

trans-unit.source: Redis enables a client application to submit a series of operations that read and write data in the cache as an atomic transaction.
trans-unit.target: Redis enables a client application to submit a series of operations that read and write data in the cache as an atomic transaction.

trans-unit.source: All of the commands in the transaction are guaranteed to be executed sequentially and no commands issued by other concurrent clients will be interwoven between them.
trans-unit.target: All of the commands in the transaction are guaranteed to be executed sequentially and no commands issued by other concurrent clients will be interwoven between them.

trans-unit.source: However, these are not true transactions as a relational database would perform them.
trans-unit.target: However, these are not true transactions as a relational database would perform them.

trans-unit.source: Transaction processing consists of two stages; command queuing and command execution.
trans-unit.target: Transaction processing consists of two stages; command queuing and command execution.

trans-unit.source: During the command queuing stage, the commands that comprise the transaction are submitted by the client.
trans-unit.target: During the command queuing stage, the commands that comprise the transaction are submitted by the client.

trans-unit.source: If some sort of error occurs at this point (such as a syntax error, or the wrong number of parameters) then Redis will refuse to process the entire transaction and discard it.
trans-unit.target: If some sort of error occurs at this point (such as a syntax error, or the wrong number of parameters) then Redis will refuse to process the entire transaction and discard it.

trans-unit.source: During the execution phase, Redis performs each queued command in sequence.
trans-unit.target: During the execution phase, Redis performs each queued command in sequence.

trans-unit.source: If a command fails during this phase Redis will continue with the next queued command and it does not roll back the effects of any commands that have already been executed.
trans-unit.target: If a command fails during this phase Redis will continue with the next queued command and it does not roll back the effects of any commands that have already been executed.

trans-unit.source: This simplified form of transaction helps to maintain performance and avoid performance problems caused by contention.
trans-unit.target: This simplified form of transaction helps to maintain performance and avoid performance problems caused by contention.

trans-unit.source: Redis does implement a form of optimistic locking to assist in maintaining consistency.
trans-unit.target: Redis does implement a form of optimistic locking to assist in maintaining consistency.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information about transactions and locking with Redis, visit the [Transactions page](http://redis.io/topics/transactions) on the Redis website.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information about transactions and locking with Redis, visit the [Transactions page](http://redis.io/topics/transactions) on the Redis website.

trans-unit.source: Redis also supports non-transactional batching of requests.
trans-unit.target: Redis also supports non-transactional batching of requests.

trans-unit.source: The Redis protocol that clients use to send commands to a Redis server enables a client to send a series of operations as part of the same request.
trans-unit.target: The Redis protocol that clients use to send commands to a Redis server enables a client to send a series of operations as part of the same request.

trans-unit.source: This can help to reduce packet fragmentation on the network.
trans-unit.target: This can help to reduce packet fragmentation on the network.

trans-unit.source: When the batch is processed, each command is performed.
trans-unit.target: When the batch is processed, each command is performed.

trans-unit.source: Unlike a transaction, if any of these commands are malformed they will be rejected but the remaining commands will be performed.
trans-unit.target: Unlike a transaction, if any of these commands are malformed they will be rejected but the remaining commands will be performed.

trans-unit.source: There is also no guarantee on the order in which the commands in the batch will be processed.
trans-unit.target: There is also no guarantee on the order in which the commands in the batch will be processed.

trans-unit.source: Redis security
trans-unit.target: Redis security

trans-unit.source: Redis is focused purely on providing fast access to data, and is designed to run inside a trusted environment and be accessed only by trusted clients.
trans-unit.target: Redis is focused purely on providing fast access to data, and is designed to run inside a trusted environment and be accessed only by trusted clients.

trans-unit.source: Redis only supports a limited security model based on password authentication (it is possible to remove authentication completely, although this is not recommended).
trans-unit.target: Redis only supports a limited security model based on password authentication (it is possible to remove authentication completely, although this is not recommended).

trans-unit.source: All authenticated clients share the same global password, and have access to the same resources.
trans-unit.target: All authenticated clients share the same global password, and have access to the same resources.

trans-unit.source: If you need more comprehensive login security, you must implement your own security layer in front of the Redis server and all client requests should pass through this additional layer; Redis should not be directly exposed to untrusted or unauthenticated clients.
trans-unit.target: If you need more comprehensive login security, you must implement your own security layer in front of the Redis server and all client requests should pass through this additional layer; Redis should not be directly exposed to untrusted or unauthenticated clients.

trans-unit.source: You can restrict access to commands by disabling them or renaming them (and only providing privileged clients with the new names).
trans-unit.target: You can restrict access to commands by disabling them or renaming them (and only providing privileged clients with the new names).

trans-unit.source: Redis does not directly support any form of data encryption, so all encoding must be performed by client applications.
trans-unit.target: Redis does not directly support any form of data encryption, so all encoding must be performed by client applications.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, Redis does not provide any form of transport security, so if you need to protect data as it flows across the network you should implement an SSL proxy.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, Redis does not provide any form of transport security, so if you need to protect data as it flows across the network you should implement an SSL proxy.

trans-unit.source: For more information, visit the [Redis Security](http://redis.io/topics/security) page on the Redis website.
trans-unit.target: For more information, visit the [Redis Security](http://redis.io/topics/security) page on the Redis website.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Redis Cache provides its own security layer through which clients connect; the underlying Redis
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Redis Cache provides its own security layer through which clients connect; the underlying Redis

trans-unit.source: servers are not exposed to the public network.
trans-unit.target: servers are not exposed to the public network.

trans-unit.source: Using the Azure Redis cache
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure Redis cache

trans-unit.source: The Azure Redis Cache provides access to Redis servers running on servers hosted at an Azure datacenter; it acts as a façade that provides access control and security.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Redis Cache provides access to Redis servers running on servers hosted at an Azure datacenter; it acts as a façade that provides access control and security.

trans-unit.source: You can provision a cache by using the Azure Management portal.
trans-unit.target: You can provision a cache by using the Azure Management portal.

trans-unit.source: The portal provides a number of predefined configurations, ranging from a 53GB cache running as a dedicated service that supports SSL communications (for privacy) and master/subordinate replication with an SLA of 99.9% availability, down to a 250MB cache without replication (no availability guarantees) running on shared hardware.
trans-unit.target: The portal provides a number of predefined configurations, ranging from a 53GB cache running as a dedicated service that supports SSL communications (for privacy) and master/subordinate replication with an SLA of 99.9% availability, down to a 250MB cache without replication (no availability guarantees) running on shared hardware.

trans-unit.source: Using the Azure Management portal you can also configure the eviction policy of the cache, and control access to the cache by adding users to the roles provided; Owner, Contributor, Reader.
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure Management portal you can also configure the eviction policy of the cache, and control access to the cache by adding users to the roles provided; Owner, Contributor, Reader.

trans-unit.source: These roles define the operations that members can perform.
trans-unit.target: These roles define the operations that members can perform.

trans-unit.source: For example, members of the Owner role have complete control over the cache (including security) and its contents, members of the Contributor role can read and write information in the cache, and members of the Reader role can only retrieve data from the cache.
trans-unit.target: For example, members of the Owner role have complete control over the cache (including security) and its contents, members of the Contributor role can read and write information in the cache, and members of the Reader role can only retrieve data from the cache.

trans-unit.source: Most administrative tasks are performed through the Azure Management portal, and for this reason many of the administrative commands available in the standard version of Redis are not available, including the ability to modify the configuration programmatically, shutdown the Redis server, configure additional slaves, or forcibly save data to disk.
trans-unit.target: Most administrative tasks are performed through the Azure Management portal, and for this reason many of the administrative commands available in the standard version of Redis are not available, including the ability to modify the configuration programmatically, shutdown the Redis server, configure additional slaves, or forcibly save data to disk.

trans-unit.source: The Azure management portal includes a convenient graphical display that enables you to monitor the performance of the cache.
trans-unit.target: The Azure management portal includes a convenient graphical display that enables you to monitor the performance of the cache.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can view the number of connections being made, the number of requests performed, the volume of reads and writes, and the number of cache hits versus cache misses.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can view the number of connections being made, the number of requests performed, the volume of reads and writes, and the number of cache hits versus cache misses.

trans-unit.source: Using this information you can determine the effectiveness of the cache and if necessary switch to a different configuration or change the eviction policy.
trans-unit.target: Using this information you can determine the effectiveness of the cache and if necessary switch to a different configuration or change the eviction policy.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, you can create alerts that send email messages to an administrator if one or more critical metrics fall outside of an expected range.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, you can create alerts that send email messages to an administrator if one or more critical metrics fall outside of an expected range.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the number of cache misses exceeds a specified value in the last hour, an administrator could be alerted as the cache may be too small or data may be being evicted too quickly.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the number of cache misses exceeds a specified value in the last hour, an administrator could be alerted as the cache may be too small or data may be being evicted too quickly.

trans-unit.source: You can also monitor CPU, memory, and network usage for the cache.
trans-unit.target: You can also monitor CPU, memory, and network usage for the cache.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Redis Cache is intended to act purely as a cache rather than a database.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Redis Cache is intended to act purely as a cache rather than a database.

trans-unit.source: As a result, it does not currently implement Redis persistence.
trans-unit.target: As a result, it does not currently implement Redis persistence.

trans-unit.source: For further information and examples showing how to create and configure an Azure Redis Cache, visit the page [Lap around Azure Redis Cache](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/06/04/lap-around-azure-redis-cache-preview/) on the Azure blog.
trans-unit.target: For further information and examples showing how to create and configure an Azure Redis Cache, visit the page [Lap around Azure Redis Cache](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/06/04/lap-around-azure-redis-cache-preview/) on the Azure blog.

trans-unit.source: Caching session state and HTML output
trans-unit.target: Caching session state and HTML output

trans-unit.source: If you building ASP.NET web applications that run by using Azure web roles, you can save session state information and HTML output in an Azure Redis Cache.
trans-unit.target: If you building ASP.NET web applications that run by using Azure web roles, you can save session state information and HTML output in an Azure Redis Cache.

trans-unit.source: The Session State Provider for Azure Redis Cache enables you to share session information between different instances of an ASP.NET web application, and is very useful in web farm situations where client-server affinity is not available and caching session data in-memory would not be appropriate.
trans-unit.target: The Session State Provider for Azure Redis Cache enables you to share session information between different instances of an ASP.NET web application, and is very useful in web farm situations where client-server affinity is not available and caching session data in-memory would not be appropriate.

trans-unit.source: Using the Session State Provider with Azure Redis Cache delivers several benefits, including:
trans-unit.target: Using the Session State Provider with Azure Redis Cache delivers several benefits, including:

trans-unit.source: It can share session state amongst a large number of instances of an ASP.NET web application, providing improved scalability,
trans-unit.target: It can share session state amongst a large number of instances of an ASP.NET web application, providing improved scalability,

trans-unit.source: It supports controlled, concurrent access to the same session state data for multiple readers and a single writer, and
trans-unit.target: It supports controlled, concurrent access to the same session state data for multiple readers and a single writer, and

trans-unit.source: It can use compression to save memory and improve network performance.
trans-unit.target: It can use compression to save memory and improve network performance.

trans-unit.source: For more information visit the [ASP.NET Session State Provider for Azure Redis Cache](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn690522.aspx) page on the Microsoft website.
trans-unit.target: For more information visit the [ASP.NET Session State Provider for Azure Redis Cache](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn690522.aspx) page on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Do not use the Session State Provider for Azure Redis Cache for ASP.NET applications that run outside of the Azure environment.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Do not use the Session State Provider for Azure Redis Cache for ASP.NET applications that run outside of the Azure environment.

trans-unit.source: The latency of accessing the cache from outside of Azure can eliminate the performance benefits of caching data.
trans-unit.target: The latency of accessing the cache from outside of Azure can eliminate the performance benefits of caching data.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the Output Cache Provider for Azure Redis Cache enables you to save the HTTP responses generated by an ASP.NET web application.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the Output Cache Provider for Azure Redis Cache enables you to save the HTTP responses generated by an ASP.NET web application.

trans-unit.source: Using the Output Cache Provider with Azure Redis Cache can improve the response times of applications that render complex HTML output; application instances generating similar responses can make use of the shared output fragments in the cache rather than generating this HTML output afresh.
trans-unit.target: Using the Output Cache Provider with Azure Redis Cache can improve the response times of applications that render complex HTML output; application instances generating similar responses can make use of the shared output fragments in the cache rather than generating this HTML output afresh.

trans-unit.source: For more information visit the [ASP.NET Output Cache Provider for Azure Redis Cache](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn798898.aspx) page on the Microsoft website.
trans-unit.target: For more information visit the [ASP.NET Output Cache Provider for Azure Redis Cache](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn798898.aspx) page on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: Building a custom Redis cache
trans-unit.target: Building a custom Redis cache

trans-unit.source: The Azure Redis cache acts as a façade to the underlying Redis servers.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Redis cache acts as a façade to the underlying Redis servers.

trans-unit.source: Currently it supports a fixed set of configurations but does not provide for Redis clustering.
trans-unit.target: Currently it supports a fixed set of configurations but does not provide for Redis clustering.

trans-unit.source: If you require an advanced configuration that is not covered by the Azure Redis cache (such as a cache bigger than 53GB) you can build and host your own Redis servers by using Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: If you require an advanced configuration that is not covered by the Azure Redis cache (such as a cache bigger than 53GB) you can build and host your own Redis servers by using Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: This is a potentially complex process as you may need to create several VMs to act as master and subordinate nodes if you want to implement replication.
trans-unit.target: This is a potentially complex process as you may need to create several VMs to act as master and subordinate nodes if you want to implement replication.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, if you wish to create a cluster, then you will need multiple masters and subordinate servers; a minimal clustered, replication topology that provides a high degree of availability and scalability comprises at least 6 VMs organized as 3 pairs of master/subordinate servers (a cluster must contain at least 3 master nodes).
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, if you wish to create a cluster, then you will need multiple masters and subordinate servers; a minimal clustered, replication topology that provides a high degree of availability and scalability comprises at least 6 VMs organized as 3 pairs of master/subordinate servers (a cluster must contain at least 3 master nodes).

trans-unit.source: Each master/subordinate pair should be located close together to minimize latency, but each set of pairs can be running in different Azure datacenters located in different regions if you wish to locate cached data close to the applications that are most likely to use it.
trans-unit.target: Each master/subordinate pair should be located close together to minimize latency, but each set of pairs can be running in different Azure datacenters located in different regions if you wish to locate cached data close to the applications that are most likely to use it.

trans-unit.source: The page [Running Redis on a CentOS Linux VM in Azure](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/tconte/archive/2012/06/08/running-redis-on-a-centos-linux-vm-in-windows-azure.aspx) on the Microsoft website walks through an example showing how to build and configure a Redis node running as an Azure VM.
trans-unit.target: The page [Running Redis on a CentOS Linux VM in Azure](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/tconte/archive/2012/06/08/running-redis-on-a-centos-linux-vm-in-windows-azure.aspx) on the Microsoft website walks through an example showing how to build and configure a Redis node running as an Azure VM.

trans-unit.source: Note that if you implement your own Redis cache in this way, you are responsible for monitoring, managing, and securing the service.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you implement your own Redis cache in this way, you are responsible for monitoring, managing, and securing the service.

trans-unit.source: Partitioning a Redis cache
trans-unit.target: Partitioning a Redis cache

trans-unit.source: Partitioning the cache involves splitting the cache across multiple computers.
trans-unit.target: Partitioning the cache involves splitting the cache across multiple computers.

trans-unit.source: This structure gives you several advantages over using a single cache server, including:
trans-unit.target: This structure gives you several advantages over using a single cache server, including:

trans-unit.source: Creating a cache that is much bigger than can be stored on a single server.
trans-unit.target: Creating a cache that is much bigger than can be stored on a single server.

trans-unit.source: Distributing data across servers, improving availability.
trans-unit.target: Distributing data across servers, improving availability.

trans-unit.source: If one server fails or becomes inaccessible, only the data that it holds is unavailable; the data on the remaining servers can still be accessed.
trans-unit.target: If one server fails or becomes inaccessible, only the data that it holds is unavailable; the data on the remaining servers can still be accessed.

trans-unit.source: For a cache, this is not crucial as the cached data is only a transient copy of the data held in a database, and cached data on a server that becomes inaccessible can be cached on a different server instead.
trans-unit.target: For a cache, this is not crucial as the cached data is only a transient copy of the data held in a database, and cached data on a server that becomes inaccessible can be cached on a different server instead.

trans-unit.source: Spreading the load across servers, thereby improving performance and scalability.
trans-unit.target: Spreading the load across servers, thereby improving performance and scalability.

trans-unit.source: Geolocating data close to the users that access it, reducing latency.
trans-unit.target: Geolocating data close to the users that access it, reducing latency.

trans-unit.source: For a cache, the most common form of partitioning is sharding.
trans-unit.target: For a cache, the most common form of partitioning is sharding.

trans-unit.source: In this strategy each partition (or shard) is a Redis cache in its own right.
trans-unit.target: In this strategy each partition (or shard) is a Redis cache in its own right.

trans-unit.source: Data is directed to a specific partition by using sharding logic, which can use a variety of approaches to distribute the data.
trans-unit.target: Data is directed to a specific partition by using sharding logic, which can use a variety of approaches to distribute the data.

trans-unit.source: The [Sharding Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589797.aspx) provides more information on implementing sharding.
trans-unit.target: The [Sharding Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589797.aspx) provides more information on implementing sharding.

trans-unit.source: Implementing Redis cache client applications
trans-unit.target: Implementing Redis cache client applications

trans-unit.source: Redis supports client applications written in numerous programming languages.
trans-unit.target: Redis supports client applications written in numerous programming languages.

trans-unit.source: If you are building new applications by using the .NET Framework, the recommended approach is to use the StackExchange.Redis client library.
trans-unit.target: If you are building new applications by using the .NET Framework, the recommended approach is to use the StackExchange.Redis client library.

trans-unit.source: This library provides a .NET Framework object model that abstracts the details for connecting to a Redis server, sending commands, and receiving responses.
trans-unit.target: This library provides a .NET Framework object model that abstracts the details for connecting to a Redis server, sending commands, and receiving responses.

trans-unit.source: It is available in Visual Studio as a NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: It is available in Visual Studio as a NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: You can use this same library to connect to an Azure Redis cache, or a custom Redis cache hosted on a VM.
trans-unit.target: You can use this same library to connect to an Azure Redis cache, or a custom Redis cache hosted on a VM.

trans-unit.source: To connect to a Redis server you use the static `Connect` method of the `ConnectionMultiplexer` class.
trans-unit.target: To connect to a Redis server you use the static `Connect` method of the `ConnectionMultiplexer` class.

trans-unit.source: The connection that this method creates is designed to be used throughout the lifetime of the client application, and the same connection can be used by multiple concurrent threads; do not reconnect and disconnect each time you perform a Redis operation as this can degrade performance.
trans-unit.target: The connection that this method creates is designed to be used throughout the lifetime of the client application, and the same connection can be used by multiple concurrent threads; do not reconnect and disconnect each time you perform a Redis operation as this can degrade performance.

trans-unit.source: You can specify the connection parameters, such as the address of the Redis host and the password.
trans-unit.target: You can specify the connection parameters, such as the address of the Redis host and the password.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the Azure Redis cache, the password this is either the primary or secondary key generated for the Azure Redis Cache by using the Azure Management portal.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the Azure Redis cache, the password this is either the primary or secondary key generated for the Azure Redis Cache by using the Azure Management portal.

trans-unit.source: After you have connected to the Redis server, you can obtain a handle on the Redis database that acts as the cache.
trans-unit.target: After you have connected to the Redis server, you can obtain a handle on the Redis database that acts as the cache.

trans-unit.source: The Redis connection provides the `GetDatabase` method to do this.
trans-unit.target: The Redis connection provides the `GetDatabase` method to do this.

trans-unit.source: You can then retrieve items from the cache and store data in the cache by using the `StringGet` and `StringSet` methods.
trans-unit.target: You can then retrieve items from the cache and store data in the cache by using the `StringGet` and `StringSet` methods.

trans-unit.source: These methods expect a key as a parameter, and either return the item in the cache that has a matching value (`StringGet`) or add the item to the cache with this key (`StringSet`).
trans-unit.target: These methods expect a key as a parameter, and either return the item in the cache that has a matching value (`StringGet`) or add the item to the cache with this key (`StringSet`).

trans-unit.source: Depending on the location of the Redis server, many operations may incur some latency while a request is transmitted to the server and a response returned to the client.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the location of the Redis server, many operations may incur some latency while a request is transmitted to the server and a response returned to the client.

trans-unit.source: The StackExchange library provides asynchronous versions of many of the methods that it exposes to help client applications remain responsive.
trans-unit.target: The StackExchange library provides asynchronous versions of many of the methods that it exposes to help client applications remain responsive.

trans-unit.source: These methods support the [Task-based Asynchronous Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh873175.aspx) in the .NET Framework.
trans-unit.target: These methods support the [Task-based Asynchronous Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh873175.aspx) in the .NET Framework.

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet shows a method named `RetrieveItem` that illustrates an example of an implementation of the cache-aside pattern based on Redis and the StackExchange library.
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet shows a method named `RetrieveItem` that illustrates an example of an implementation of the cache-aside pattern based on Redis and the StackExchange library.

trans-unit.source: The method takes a string key value, and attempts to retrieve the corresponding item from the Redis cache by calling the `StringGetAsync` method (the asynchronous version of `StringGet`).
trans-unit.target: The method takes a string key value, and attempts to retrieve the corresponding item from the Redis cache by calling the `StringGetAsync` method (the asynchronous version of `StringGet`).

trans-unit.source: If the item is not found, it is fetched from the underlying data source using the `GetItemFromDataSourceAsync` method (which is a local method and not part of the StackExchange library), and then added to the cache by using the `StringSetAsync` method so it can be retrieved more quickly next time.
trans-unit.target: If the item is not found, it is fetched from the underlying data source using the `GetItemFromDataSourceAsync` method (which is a local method and not part of the StackExchange library), and then added to the cache by using the `StringSetAsync` method so it can be retrieved more quickly next time.

trans-unit.source: The `StringGet` and `StringSet` methods are not restricted to retrieving or storing string values; they can take any item serialized as an array of bytes.
trans-unit.target: The `StringGet` and `StringSet` methods are not restricted to retrieving or storing string values; they can take any item serialized as an array of bytes.

trans-unit.source: If you need to save a .NET object you can serialize it as a byte stream and use the StringSet method to write it to the cache.
trans-unit.target: If you need to save a .NET object you can serialize it as a byte stream and use the StringSet method to write it to the cache.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, you can read an object from cache by using the StringGet method and deserialize it as a .NET object.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, you can read an object from cache by using the StringGet method and deserialize it as a .NET object.

trans-unit.source: Redis supports command pipelining if a client application sends multiple asynchronous requests.
trans-unit.target: Redis supports command pipelining if a client application sends multiple asynchronous requests.

trans-unit.source: Redis can multiplex the requests using the same connection rather than receiving and responding to commands in a strict sequence.
trans-unit.target: Redis can multiplex the requests using the same connection rather than receiving and responding to commands in a strict sequence.

trans-unit.source: This approach helps to reduce latency by making more efficient use of the network.
trans-unit.target: This approach helps to reduce latency by making more efficient use of the network.

trans-unit.source: The section Use-Cases for Redis Caching later in this guidance provides examples of some of the more advanced techniques that you can apply to data held in a Redis cache.
trans-unit.target: The section Use-Cases for Redis Caching later in this guidance provides examples of some of the more advanced techniques that you can apply to data held in a Redis cache.

trans-unit.source: Use-cases for Redis caching
trans-unit.target: Use-cases for Redis caching

trans-unit.source: The simplest use of Redis for caching concerns storing key/value pairs where the value is an uninterpreted string of arbitrary length that can contain any binary data (it is essentially an array of bytes that can be treated as a string).
trans-unit.target: The simplest use of Redis for caching concerns storing key/value pairs where the value is an uninterpreted string of arbitrary length that can contain any binary data (it is essentially an array of bytes that can be treated as a string).

trans-unit.source: This scenario was illustrated in the section Implementing Redis Cache Client Applications earlier in this guidance.
trans-unit.target: This scenario was illustrated in the section Implementing Redis Cache Client Applications earlier in this guidance.

trans-unit.source: You should note that keys also contain uninterpreted data, so you can use any binary information as the key, although the longer the key is the more space it will take to store, and the longer it will take to perform lookup operations.
trans-unit.target: You should note that keys also contain uninterpreted data, so you can use any binary information as the key, although the longer the key is the more space it will take to store, and the longer it will take to perform lookup operations.

trans-unit.source: For usability and ease of maintenance design your keyspace carefully and use meaningful (but not verbose) keys.
trans-unit.target: For usability and ease of maintenance design your keyspace carefully and use meaningful (but not verbose) keys.

trans-unit.source: For example, use structured keys such as "customer:100" to represent the key for the customer with ID 100 rather than simply "100".
trans-unit.target: For example, use structured keys such as "customer:100" to represent the key for the customer with ID 100 rather than simply "100".

trans-unit.source: This scheme enables you to easily distinguish between values that store different data types.
trans-unit.target: This scheme enables you to easily distinguish between values that store different data types.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could also use the key "orders:100" to represent the key for the order with ID 100.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could also use the key "orders:100" to represent the key for the order with ID 100.

trans-unit.source: Apart from one-dimensional binary strings, a value in a Redis key/value pair can also hold more structured information, including lists, sets (sorted and unsorted), and hashes.
trans-unit.target: Apart from one-dimensional binary strings, a value in a Redis key/value pair can also hold more structured information, including lists, sets (sorted and unsorted), and hashes.

trans-unit.source: Redis provides a comprehensive command set that can manipulate these types, and many of these commands are available to .NET Framework applications through a client library such as StackExchange.
trans-unit.target: Redis provides a comprehensive command set that can manipulate these types, and many of these commands are available to .NET Framework applications through a client library such as StackExchange.

trans-unit.source: The page [An introduction to Redis data types and abstractions](http://redis.io/topics/data-types-intro) on the Redis website provides a more detailed overview of these types and the commands that you can use to manipulate them.
trans-unit.target: The page [An introduction to Redis data types and abstractions](http://redis.io/topics/data-types-intro) on the Redis website provides a more detailed overview of these types and the commands that you can use to manipulate them.

trans-unit.source: This section summarizes some common use-cases for these data types and commands.
trans-unit.target: This section summarizes some common use-cases for these data types and commands.

trans-unit.target: Performing atomic and batch operations

trans-unit.source: Redis supports a series of atomic get-and-set operations on string values.
trans-unit.target: Redis supports a series of atomic get-and-set operations on string values.

trans-unit.source: These operations remove the possible race hazards that might occur when using separate `GET` and `SET` commands.
trans-unit.target: These operations remove the possible race hazards that might occur when using separate `GET` and `SET` commands.

trans-unit.target: The operations available include:

trans-unit.target: `INCR`, `INCRBY`, `DECR`, and `DECRBY` which perform atomic increment and decrement operations on

trans-unit.source: integer numeric data values.
trans-unit.target: integer numeric data values.

trans-unit.source: You can also combine multiple operations into a single Redis transaction as described in the Redis Transactions and Batches section in this guidance.
trans-unit.target: You can also combine multiple operations into a single Redis transaction as described in the Redis Transactions and Batches section in this guidance.

trans-unit.source: The StackExchange library provides support for transactions through the `ITransaction` interface.
trans-unit.target: The StackExchange library provides support for transactions through the `ITransaction` interface.

trans-unit.source: You can create an ITransaction object by using the IDatabase.CreateTransaction method, and invoke commands to the transaction by using the methods provided `ITransaction` object.
trans-unit.target: You can create an ITransaction object by using the IDatabase.CreateTransaction method, and invoke commands to the transaction by using the methods provided `ITransaction` object.

trans-unit.source: The `ITransaction` interface provides access to a similar set of methods as the `IDatabase` interface except that all the methods are asynchronous; they are only performed when the `ITransaction.Execute` method is invoked.
trans-unit.target: The `ITransaction` interface provides access to a similar set of methods as the `IDatabase` interface except that all the methods are asynchronous; they are only performed when the `ITransaction.Execute` method is invoked.

trans-unit.source: The value returned by the execute method indicates whether the transaction was created successfully (true) or it failed (false).
trans-unit.target: The value returned by the execute method indicates whether the transaction was created successfully (true) or it failed (false).

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet shows an example that increments and decrements two counters as part of the same transaction:
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet shows an example that increments and decrements two counters as part of the same transaction:

trans-unit.source: Remember that Redis transactions are unlike transactions in relational databases.
trans-unit.target: Remember that Redis transactions are unlike transactions in relational databases.

trans-unit.source: The Execute method simply queues all the commands that comprise the transaction for execution, and if any of them is malformed then the transaction is aborted.
trans-unit.target: The Execute method simply queues all the commands that comprise the transaction for execution, and if any of them is malformed then the transaction is aborted.

trans-unit.source: If all the commands have been queued successfully, each command will be run asynchronously.
trans-unit.target: If all the commands have been queued successfully, each command will be run asynchronously.

trans-unit.source: If any command fails, the others will still continue processing.
trans-unit.target: If any command fails, the others will still continue processing.

trans-unit.source: If you need to verify that a command has completed successfully you must fetch the results of the command by using the Result property of the corresponding task, as shown in the example above.
trans-unit.target: If you need to verify that a command has completed successfully you must fetch the results of the command by using the Result property of the corresponding task, as shown in the example above.

trans-unit.source: Reading the Result property will block until the task has completed.
trans-unit.target: Reading the Result property will block until the task has completed.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Transactions in Redis](https://github.com/StackExchange/StackExchange.Redis/blob/master/Docs/Transactions.md) page on the StackExchange.Redis website.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Transactions in Redis](https://github.com/StackExchange/StackExchange.Redis/blob/master/Docs/Transactions.md) page on the StackExchange.Redis website.

trans-unit.source: For performing batch operations, you can use the IBatch interface of the StackExchange library.
trans-unit.target: For performing batch operations, you can use the IBatch interface of the StackExchange library.

trans-unit.source: This interface provides access to a similar set of methods as the IDatabase interface except that all the methods are asynchronous.
trans-unit.target: This interface provides access to a similar set of methods as the IDatabase interface except that all the methods are asynchronous.

trans-unit.source: You create an IBatch object by using the IDatabase.CreateBatch method and then run the batch by using the IBatch.Execute method, as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: You create an IBatch object by using the IDatabase.CreateBatch method and then run the batch by using the IBatch.Execute method, as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.target: This code simply sets a string value, and increments and decrements the same counters used in the previous example and displays the results:

trans-unit.source: It is important to understand that unlike a transaction, if a command in a batch fails because it is malformed the other commands may still run; the IBatch.Execute method does not return any indication of success or failure.
trans-unit.target: It is important to understand that unlike a transaction, if a command in a batch fails because it is malformed the other commands may still run; the IBatch.Execute method does not return any indication of success or failure.

trans-unit.source: Performing fire-and-forget cache operations
trans-unit.target: Performing fire-and-forget cache operations

trans-unit.source: Redis supports fire-and-forget operations by using command flags.
trans-unit.target: Redis supports fire-and-forget operations by using command flags.

trans-unit.source: In this situation, the client simply initiates an operation but has no interest in the result and does not wait for the command to be completed.
trans-unit.target: In this situation, the client simply initiates an operation but has no interest in the result and does not wait for the command to be completed.

trans-unit.source: Automatically expiring keys
trans-unit.target: Automatically expiring keys

trans-unit.source: When you store an item in a Redis cache, you can specify a timeout after which the item will be automatically removed from the cache.
trans-unit.target: When you store an item in a Redis cache, you can specify a timeout after which the item will be automatically removed from the cache.

trans-unit.source: You can also query how much more time a key has before it expires by using the `TTL` command; this command is available to StackExchange applications by using the IDatabase.KeyTimeToLive method.
trans-unit.target: You can also query how much more time a key has before it expires by using the `TTL` command; this command is available to StackExchange applications by using the IDatabase.KeyTimeToLive method.

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet shows an example of setting an expiration time of 20 seconds on a key, and querying the remaining lifetime of the key:
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet shows an example of setting an expiration time of 20 seconds on a key, and querying the remaining lifetime of the key:

trans-unit.source: You can also set the expiration time to a specific date and time by using the EXPIRE command, available in the StackExchange library as the KeyExpireAsync method:
trans-unit.target: You can also set the expiration time to a specific date and time by using the EXPIRE command, available in the StackExchange library as the KeyExpireAsync method:

trans-unit.source: _Tip:_ You can manually remove an item from the cache by using the DEL command, which is available through the StackExchange library as the IDatabase.KeyDeleteAsync method.
trans-unit.target: _Tip:_ You can manually remove an item from the cache by using the DEL command, which is available through the StackExchange library as the IDatabase.KeyDeleteAsync method.

trans-unit.source: Using tags to cross-correlate cached items
trans-unit.target: Using tags to cross-correlate cached items

trans-unit.source: A Redis set is a collection of multiple items that share a single key.
trans-unit.target: A Redis set is a collection of multiple items that share a single key.

trans-unit.source: You can create a set by using the SADD command.
trans-unit.target: You can create a set by using the SADD command.

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve the items in a set by using the SMEMBERS command.
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve the items in a set by using the SMEMBERS command.

trans-unit.source: The StackExchange library implements the SADD command through the IDatabase.SetAddAsync method, and the SMEMBERS command with the IDatabase.SetMembersAsync method.
trans-unit.target: The StackExchange library implements the SADD command through the IDatabase.SetAddAsync method, and the SMEMBERS command with the IDatabase.SetMembersAsync method.

trans-unit.source: You can also combine existing sets to create new sets by using the SDIFF (set difference), SINTER (set intersection), and SUNION (set union) commands.
trans-unit.target: You can also combine existing sets to create new sets by using the SDIFF (set difference), SINTER (set intersection), and SUNION (set union) commands.

trans-unit.source: The StackExchange library unifies these operations in the IDatabase.SetCombineAsync method; the first parameter to this method specifies the set operation to perform.
trans-unit.target: The StackExchange library unifies these operations in the IDatabase.SetCombineAsync method; the first parameter to this method specifies the set operation to perform.

trans-unit.source: The following code snippets show how sets can be useful for quickly storing and retrieving collections of related items.
trans-unit.target: The following code snippets show how sets can be useful for quickly storing and retrieving collections of related items.

trans-unit.source: Finding recently accessed items
trans-unit.target: Finding recently accessed items

trans-unit.source: A common problem required by many applications is to find the most recently accessed items.
trans-unit.target: A common problem required by many applications is to find the most recently accessed items.

trans-unit.source: For example, a blogging site might want to display information about the most recently read blog posts.
trans-unit.target: For example, a blogging site might want to display information about the most recently read blog posts.

trans-unit.source: You can implement this functionality by using a Redis list.
trans-unit.target: You can implement this functionality by using a Redis list.

trans-unit.source: A Redis list contains multiple items that share the same key, but the list acts as a double-ended queue.
trans-unit.target: A Redis list contains multiple items that share the same key, but the list acts as a double-ended queue.

trans-unit.source: You can push items on to either end of the list by using the LPUSH (left push) and RPUSH (right push) commands.
trans-unit.target: You can push items on to either end of the list by using the LPUSH (left push) and RPUSH (right push) commands.

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve items from either end of the list by using the LPOP and RPOP commands.
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve items from either end of the list by using the LPOP and RPOP commands.

trans-unit.source: You can also return a set of elements by using the LRANGE and RRANGE commands.
trans-unit.target: You can also return a set of elements by using the LRANGE and RRANGE commands.

trans-unit.source: The code snippets below show how you can perform these operations by using the StackExchange library.
trans-unit.target: The code snippets below show how you can perform these operations by using the StackExchange library.

trans-unit.target: This code uses the BlogPost type from the previous examples.

trans-unit.source: As a blog post is read by a user, the title of the blog post is pushed onto a list associated with the key "blog:recent_posts" in the Redis cache by using the IDatabase.ListLeftPushAsync method:
trans-unit.target: As a blog post is read by a user, the title of the blog post is pushed onto a list associated with the key "blog:recent_posts" in the Redis cache by using the IDatabase.ListLeftPushAsync method:

trans-unit.source: As more blog posts are read, their titles are pushed onto the same list.
trans-unit.target: As more blog posts are read, their titles are pushed onto the same list.

trans-unit.source: The list is ordered by the sequence in which they have been added; the most recently read blog posts are towards the left end of the list (if the same blog post is read more than once, it will have multiple entries in the list).
trans-unit.target: The list is ordered by the sequence in which they have been added; the most recently read blog posts are towards the left end of the list (if the same blog post is read more than once, it will have multiple entries in the list).

trans-unit.source: You can display the titles of the most recently read posts by using the IDatabase.ListRange method.
trans-unit.target: You can display the titles of the most recently read posts by using the IDatabase.ListRange method.

trans-unit.source: Messaging by using channels
trans-unit.target: Messaging by using channels

trans-unit.source: Apart from acting as a data cache, a Redis server provides messaging through a high-performance publisher/subscriber mechanism.
trans-unit.target: Apart from acting as a data cache, a Redis server provides messaging through a high-performance publisher/subscriber mechanism.

trans-unit.source: Client applications can subscribe to a channel, and other applications or services can publish messages to the channel.
trans-unit.target: Client applications can subscribe to a channel, and other applications or services can publish messages to the channel.

trans-unit.source: Subscribing applications will then receive these messages and can process them.
trans-unit.target: Subscribing applications will then receive these messages and can process them.

trans-unit.source: To subscribe to channel, Redis provides the SUBSCRIBE command.
trans-unit.target: To subscribe to channel, Redis provides the SUBSCRIBE command.

trans-unit.source: This command expects the name of one or more channels on which the application will accept messages.
trans-unit.target: This command expects the name of one or more channels on which the application will accept messages.

trans-unit.source: The StackExchange library includes the ISubscription interface which enables a .NET Framework application to subscribe and publish to channels.
trans-unit.target: The StackExchange library includes the ISubscription interface which enables a .NET Framework application to subscribe and publish to channels.

trans-unit.source: You create an ISubscription object by using the GetSubscriber method of the connection to the Redis server, and then listen for messages on a channel by using the SubscribeAsync method of this object.
trans-unit.target: You create an ISubscription object by using the GetSubscriber method of the connection to the Redis server, and then listen for messages on a channel by using the SubscribeAsync method of this object.

trans-unit.source: The following code example shows how to subscribe to a channel named "messages:blogPosts":
trans-unit.target: The following code example shows how to subscribe to a channel named "messages:blogPosts":

trans-unit.source: The first parameter to the Subscribe method is the name of the channel.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter to the Subscribe method is the name of the channel.

trans-unit.source: This name follows the same conventions as that used by keys in the cache, and can contain any binary data, although it is advisable to use relatively short, meaningful strings to help ensure good performance and maintainability.
trans-unit.target: This name follows the same conventions as that used by keys in the cache, and can contain any binary data, although it is advisable to use relatively short, meaningful strings to help ensure good performance and maintainability.

trans-unit.source: You should also note that the namespace used by channels is separate from that used by keys, so you can have channels and keys that have the same name, although this may make your application code more difficult to maintain.
trans-unit.target: You should also note that the namespace used by channels is separate from that used by keys, so you can have channels and keys that have the same name, although this may make your application code more difficult to maintain.

trans-unit.source: The second parameter is an Action delegate.
trans-unit.target: The second parameter is an Action delegate.

trans-unit.source: This delegate runs asynchronously whenever a new message appears on the channel.
trans-unit.target: This delegate runs asynchronously whenever a new message appears on the channel.

trans-unit.source: This example simply displays the message on the console (the message will contain the title of a blog post).
trans-unit.target: This example simply displays the message on the console (the message will contain the title of a blog post).

trans-unit.source: To publish to a channel, an application can use the Redis PUBLISH command.
trans-unit.target: To publish to a channel, an application can use the Redis PUBLISH command.

trans-unit.source: The StackExchange library provides the IServer.PublishAsync method to perform this operation.
trans-unit.target: The StackExchange library provides the IServer.PublishAsync method to perform this operation.

trans-unit.source: The next code snippet shows how to publish a message to the "messages:blogPosts" channel:
trans-unit.target: The next code snippet shows how to publish a message to the "messages:blogPosts" channel:

trans-unit.source: There are several points you should understand about the publish/subscribe mechanism:
trans-unit.target: There are several points you should understand about the publish/subscribe mechanism:

trans-unit.source: Multiple subscribers can subscribe to the same channel, and they will all receive the messages published to that channel.
trans-unit.target: Multiple subscribers can subscribe to the same channel, and they will all receive the messages published to that channel.

trans-unit.source: Subscribers only receive messages that have been published after they have subscribed.
trans-unit.target: Subscribers only receive messages that have been published after they have subscribed.

trans-unit.source: Channels are not buffered, and once a message is published the Redis infrastructure pushes the message to each subscriber and then removes it.
trans-unit.target: Channels are not buffered, and once a message is published the Redis infrastructure pushes the message to each subscriber and then removes it.

trans-unit.source: By default, messages are received by subscribers in the order in which they are sent.
trans-unit.target: By default, messages are received by subscribers in the order in which they are sent.

trans-unit.source: In a highly active system with a large number
trans-unit.target: In a highly active system with a large number

trans-unit.source: of messages and many subscribers and publishers, guaranteed sequential delivery of messages can slow performance of the system.
trans-unit.target: of messages and many subscribers and publishers, guaranteed sequential delivery of messages can slow performance of the system.

trans-unit.source: If
trans-unit.target: If

trans-unit.source: each message is independent and the order is immaterial you can enable concurrent processing by the Redis system which can help to
trans-unit.target: each message is independent and the order is immaterial you can enable concurrent processing by the Redis system which can help to

trans-unit.source: improve responsiveness.
trans-unit.target: improve responsiveness.

trans-unit.source: You can achieve this in a StackExchange client by setting the PreserveAsyncOrder of the connection used by
trans-unit.target: You can achieve this in a StackExchange client by setting the PreserveAsyncOrder of the connection used by

trans-unit.source: the subscriber to false:
trans-unit.target: the subscriber to false:

trans-unit.source: Related Patterns and Guidance
trans-unit.target: Related Patterns and Guidance

trans-unit.source: The following pattern may also be relevant to your scenario when implementing caching in your applications:
trans-unit.target: The following pattern may also be relevant to your scenario when implementing caching in your applications:

trans-unit.source: [Cache-Aside Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589799.aspx): This pattern describes how to load data on-demand into a cache from a data store.
trans-unit.target: [Cache-Aside Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589799.aspx): This pattern describes how to load data on-demand into a cache from a data store.

trans-unit.source: This pattern also helps to maintain consistency between data held in the cache and the data in the original data store.
trans-unit.target: This pattern also helps to maintain consistency between data held in the cache and the data in the original data store.

trans-unit.source: The [Sharding Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589797.aspx) provides information on implementing horizontal partitioning to help improve scalability when storing and accessing large volumes of data.
trans-unit.target: The [Sharding Pattern](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn589797.aspx) provides information on implementing horizontal partitioning to help improve scalability when storing and accessing large volumes of data.
